file.content:
# Formalize Conjecture

To formalize conjecture NUM:

1. Read problem from `tidy/NUM.html`.
2. Formalize conjecture in lean and persist to `conjectures/NUM.lean`.
3. Build the file using the command `lake build conjectures/NUM.lean`.
4. Debug build until it runs successfully.

Documentation:

- Lean 4 docs: https://lean-lang.org/doc/reference/latest/
- Mathlib docs: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/

Things to consider:

- Note that build logs will throw warnings about sorry declarations. This is expected and fine for conjectures.

file.content:
OPEN This is open, and cannot be resolved with a finite computation.
Let $C\geq 0$. Is there an infinite sequence of $n_i$ such that\[\lim_{i\to \infty}\frac{p_{n_i+1}-p_{n_i}}{\log n_i}=C?\]
#5: [Er55c][Er57][Er61][Er65b][Er85c][Er90][Er97c]
number theory | primes
Disclaimer: The open status of this problem reflects the current belief of the owner of this website. There may be literature on this problem that I am unaware of, which may partially or completely solve the stated problem. Please do your own literature search before expending significant effort on solving this problem. If you find any relevant literature not mentioned here, please add this in a comment.
Let $S$ be the set of limit points of $(p_{n+1}-p_n)/\log n$. This problem asks whether $S=[0,\infty]$. Although this conjecture remains unproven, a lot is known about $S$. Some highlights:
  • $\infty\in S$ by Westzynthius' result [We31] on large prime gaps,
  • $0\in S$ by the work of Goldston, Pintz, and Yildirim [GPY09] on small prime gaps,
  • Erdős [Er55] and Ricci [Ri56] independently showed that $S$ has positive Lebesgue measure,
  • Hildebrand and Maier [HiMa88] showed that $S$ contains arbitrarily large (finite) numbers,
  • Pintz [Pi16] showed that there exists some small constant $c>0$ such that $[0,c]\subset S$,
  • Banks, Freiberg, and Maynard [BFM16] showed that at least $12.5\%$ of $[0,\infty)$ belongs to $S$,
  • Merikoski [Me20] showed that at least $1/3$ of $[0,\infty)$ belongs to $S$, and that $S$ has bounded gaps.
In [Er65b], [Er85c], and [Er97c] Erdős asks whether $S$ is everywhere dense (but Weisenberg notes that clearly $S$ is closed so this is equivalent to asking whether $S=[0,\infty]$).

See also [234].

View the LaTeX source

External data from the database - you can help update this
Formalised statement? No (Create a formalisation here)
Related OEIS sequences: A001223
2 comments on this problem
Likes this problem None
Interested in collaborating None
Currently working on this problem None
This problem looks difficult None
This problem looks tractable None
The results on this problem could be formalisable None
I am working on formalising the results on this problem None

Additional thanks to: Desmond Weisenberg

When referring to this problem, please use the original sources of Erdős. If you wish to acknowledge this website, the recommended citation format is:

T. F. Bloom, Erdős Problem #5, https://www.erdosproblems.com/5, accessed 2026-02-18
Previous
Next

content.thinking:
The conjecture is:

For any $C \geq 0$, is there an infinite sequence of $n_i$ such that 
$$\lim_{i\to \infty}\frac{p_{n_i+1}-p_{n_i}}{\log n_i}=C?$$

In other words, the set $S$ of limit points of $(p_{n+1}-p_n)/\log n$ equals $[0, \infty]$.

Let me look at some existing conjectures in the `conjectures/` folder to understand the style/format expected.

1→import Mathlib.Data.Int.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3→
     4→/--
     5→A finite system of congruences `{(aᵢ, mᵢ)}` is a **covering system** if every
     6→modulus is positive and every integer satisfies at least one congruence `n ≡ aᵢ (mod mᵢ)`.
     7→-/
     8→def IsCoveringSystem (S : Finset (ℤ × ℕ)) : Prop :=
     9→  S.Nonempty ∧
    10→  (∀ p ∈ S, 0 < p.2) ∧
    11→  (∀ n : ℤ, ∃ p ∈ S, (p.2 : ℤ) ∣ (n - p.1))
    12→
    13→/--
    14→Erdős Problem #2:
    15→
    16→Erdős asked whether the smallest modulus of a covering system can be arbitrarily
    17→large (he expected the answer to be yes). Hough (2015), building on work of
    18→Filaseta, Ford, Konyagin, Pomerance, and Yu (2007), showed the answer is **no**:
    19→every covering system has smallest modulus at most 10¹⁶. Balister, Bollobás,
    20→Morris, Sahasrabudhe, and Tiba (2022) gave a simpler proof and improved the
    21→bound to 616000. The best known lower bound is 42, due to Owens (2014).
    22→
    23→Formally: there exists an absolute constant B such that every covering system
    24→contains a congruence whose modulus is at most B.
    25→-/
    26→theorem erdos_problem_2 :
    27→    ∃ B : ℕ, ∀ S : Finset (ℤ × ℕ), IsCoveringSystem S →
    28→      ∃ p ∈ S, p.2 ≤ B :=
    29→  sorry
    30→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Int.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic

/--
A finite system of congruences `{(aᵢ, mᵢ)}` is a **covering system** if every
modulus is positive and every integer satisfies at least one congruence `n ≡ aᵢ (mod mᵢ)`.
-/
def IsCoveringSystem (S : Finset (ℤ × ℕ)) : Prop :=
  S.Nonempty ∧
  (∀ p ∈ S, 0 < p.2) ∧
  (∀ n : ℤ, ∃ p ∈ S, (p.2 : ℤ) ∣ (n - p.1))

/--
Erdős Problem #2:

Erdős asked whether the smallest modulus of a covering system can be arbitrarily
large (he expected the answer to be yes). Hough (2015), building on work of
Filaseta, Ford, Konyagin, Pomerance, and Yu (2007), showed the answer is **no**:
every covering system has smallest modulus at most 10¹⁶. Balister, Bollobás,
Morris, Sahasrabudhe, and Tiba (2022) gave a simpler proof and improved the
bound to 616000. The best known lower bound is 42, due to Owens (2014).

Formally: there exists an absolute constant B such that every covering system
contains a congruence whose modulus is at most B.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_2 :
    ∃ B : ℕ, ∀ S : Finset (ℤ × ℕ), IsCoveringSystem S →
      ∃ p ∈ S, p.2 ≤ B :=
  sorry

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2→import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.FiniteDimensional
     3→import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Dimension.Finrank
     4→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     5→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6→import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     7→
     8→/--
     9→A finite point set in ℝ² has no five collinear if every five-element subset
    10→is not collinear (i.e., no line contains five or more of the points).
    11→-/
    12→def NoFiveCollinear (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : Prop :=
    13→  ∀ S : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),
    14→    S ⊆ P → S.card = 5 → ¬Collinear ℝ (S : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)))
    15→
    16→/--
    17→The number of 4-rich lines: the number of distinct affine lines in ℝ² that
    18→contain at least four points from P.
    19→
    20→An affine line is a 1-dimensional affine subspace (Module.finrank of its
    21→direction submodule equals 1).
    22→-/
    23→noncomputable def fourRichLineCount (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : ℕ :=
    24→  Set.ncard {L : AffineSubspace ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) |
    25→    Module.finrank ℝ L.direction = 1 ∧
    26→    4 ≤ Set.ncard {p : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2) | p ∈ (P : Set _) ∧ p ∈ L}}
    27→
    28→/--
    29→Erdős Problem #101:
    30→Given n points in ℝ², no five of which are collinear, the number of lines
    31→containing at least four of the points is o(n²).
    32→
    33→Formally: for every ε > 0 there exists N such that for all n ≥ N and every
    34→set P of n points in ℝ² with no five collinear, the count of 4-rich lines
    35→is at most ε · n².
    36→-/
    37→theorem erdos_problem_101 :
    38→  ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 →
    39→    ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N →
    40→      ∀ P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),
    41→        P.card = n →
    42→        NoFiveCollinear P →
    43→        (fourRichLineCount P : ℝ) ≤ ε * (n : ℝ) ^ 2 :=
    44→  sorry
    45→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.FiniteDimensional
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Dimension.Finrank
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card

/--
A finite point set in ℝ² has no five collinear if every five-element subset
is not collinear (i.e., no line contains five or more of the points).
-/
def NoFiveCollinear (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : Prop :=
  ∀ S : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),
    S ⊆ P → S.card = 5 → ¬Collinear ℝ (S : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)))

/--
The number of 4-rich lines: the number of distinct affine lines in ℝ² that
contain at least four points from P.

An affine line is a 1-dimensional affine subspace (Module.finrank of its
direction submodule equals 1).
-/
noncomputable def fourRichLineCount (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : ℕ :=
  Set.ncard {L : AffineSubspace ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) |
    Module.finrank ℝ L.direction = 1 ∧
    4 ≤ Set.ncard {p : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2) | p ∈ (P : Set _) ∧ p ∈ L}}

/--
Erdős Problem #101:
Given n points in ℝ², no five of which are collinear, the number of lines
containing at least four of the points is o(n²).

Formally: for every ε > 0 there exists N such that for all n ≥ N and every
set P of n points in ℝ² with no five collinear, the count of 4-rich lines
is at most ε · n².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_101 :
  ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 →
    ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N →
      ∀ P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),
        P.card = n →
        NoFiveCollinear P →
        (fourRichLineCount P : ℝ) ≤ ε * (n : ℝ) ^ 2 :=
  sorry

content.thinking: Let me also look at a prime-related conjecture to see how primes are handled in Mathlib.

content.text: Let me look at a prime-related conjecture for style reference.

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Nth
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient
     4→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Sort
     5→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6→import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     7→import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     8→import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic
     9→import Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Ring.Real
    10→
    11→open Finset Filter Nat BigOperators Classical
    12→
    13→noncomputable section
    14→
    15→/-!
    16→# Erdős Problem #235
    17→
    18→Let Nₖ = 2·3·…·pₖ (the k-th primorial) and let a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ < a_{φ(Nₖ)}
    19→be the integers less than Nₖ coprime to Nₖ. Then for any c ≥ 0, the limit
    20→
    21→  lim_{k→∞} #{i : aᵢ - aᵢ₋₁ ≤ c·Nₖ/φ(Nₖ)} / φ(Nₖ)
    22→
    23→exists and defines a continuous function of c.
    24→
    25→Proved by Hooley [Ho65], who showed that the limiting distribution is
    26→exponential: f(c) = 1 - e^{-c}.
    27→-/
    28→
    29→/-- The k-th primorial: product of the first k primes (p₁ · p₂ · … · pₖ). -/
    30→def primorial (k : ℕ) : ℕ := ∏ i ∈ Finset.range k, nth Nat.Prime i
    31→
    32→/-- The sorted list of natural numbers less than n that are coprime to n. -/
    33→def sortedCoprimes (n : ℕ) : List ℕ :=
    34→  ((Finset.range n).filter (fun a => Nat.Coprime a n)).sort (· ≤ ·)
    35→
    36→/-- Count consecutive gaps ≤ threshold in a sorted list of naturals. -/
    37→def countSmallGaps : List ℕ → ℝ → ℕ
    38→  | [], _ => 0
    39→  | [_], _ => 0
    40→  | a :: b :: rest, threshold =>
    41→    (if ((b : ℝ) - (a : ℝ)) ≤ threshold then 1 else 0) + countSmallGaps (b :: rest) threshold
    42→
    43→/-- The fraction of consecutive gaps among reduced residues mod Nₖ
    44→    that are at most c · Nₖ / φ(Nₖ). -/
    45→def gapFraction (k : ℕ) (c : ℝ) : ℝ :=
    46→  let Nk := primorial k
    47→  let residues := sortedCoprimes Nk
    48→  let threshold := c * (Nk : ℝ) / (Nat.totient Nk : ℝ)
    49→  (countSmallGaps residues threshold : ℝ) / (Nat.totient Nk : ℝ)
    50→
    51→/--
    52→Erdős Problem #235 [Er55c] (proved by Hooley [Ho65]):
    53→
    54→Let Nₖ = 2·3·…·pₖ (the k-th primorial) and let a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ < a_{φ(Nₖ)}
    55→be the integers less than Nₖ coprime to Nₖ. Then for any c ≥ 0, the limit
    56→
    57→  lim_{k→∞} #{i : aᵢ - aᵢ₋₁ ≤ c·Nₖ/φ(Nₖ)} / φ(Nₖ)
    58→
    59→exists and defines a continuous function of c.
    60→
    61→Hooley proved that the limiting distribution is exponential: f(c) = 1 - e^{-c}.
    62→-/
    63→theorem erdos235 :
    64→    ∃ f : ℝ → ℝ, Continuous f ∧
    65→      ∀ c : ℝ, 0 ≤ c →
    66→        Tendsto (fun k => gapFraction k c) atTop (nhds (f c)) :=
    67→  sorry
    68→
    69→end
    70→

import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Nth
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Sort
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic
import Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Ring.Real

open Finset Filter Nat BigOperators Classical

noncomputable section

/-!
# Erdős Problem #235

Let Nₖ = 2·3·…·pₖ (the k-th primorial) and let a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ < a_{φ(Nₖ)}
be the integers less than Nₖ coprime to Nₖ. Then for any c ≥ 0, the limit

  lim_{k→∞} #{i : aᵢ - aᵢ₋₁ ≤ c·Nₖ/φ(Nₖ)} / φ(Nₖ)

exists and defines a continuous function of c.

Proved by Hooley [Ho65], who showed that the limiting distribution is
exponential: f(c) = 1 - e^{-c}.
-/

/-- The k-th primorial: product of the first k primes (p₁ · p₂ · … · pₖ). -/
def primorial (k : ℕ) : ℕ := ∏ i ∈ Finset.range k, nth Nat.Prime i

/-- The sorted list of natural numbers less than n that are coprime to n. -/
def sortedCoprimes (n : ℕ) : List ℕ :=
  ((Finset.range n).filter (fun a => Nat.Coprime a n)).sort (· ≤ ·)

/-- Count consecutive gaps ≤ threshold in a sorted list of naturals. -/
def countSmallGaps : List ℕ → ℝ → ℕ
  | [], _ => 0
  | [_], _ => 0
  | a :: b :: rest, threshold =>
    (if ((b : ℝ) - (a : ℝ)) ≤ threshold then 1 else 0) + countSmallGaps (b :: rest) threshold

/-- The fraction of consecutive gaps among reduced residues mod Nₖ
    that are at most c · Nₖ / φ(Nₖ). -/
def gapFraction (k : ℕ) (c : ℝ) : ℝ :=
  let Nk := primorial k
  let residues := sortedCoprimes Nk
  let threshold := c * (Nk : ℝ) / (Nat.totient Nk : ℝ)
  (countSmallGaps residues threshold : ℝ) / (Nat.totient Nk : ℝ)

/--
Erdős Problem #235 [Er55c] (proved by Hooley [Ho65]):

Let Nₖ = 2·3·…·pₖ (the k-th primorial) and let a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ < a_{φ(Nₖ)}
be the integers less than Nₖ coprime to Nₖ. Then for any c ≥ 0, the limit

  lim_{k→∞} #{i : aᵢ - aᵢ₋₁ ≤ c·Nₖ/φ(Nₖ)} / φ(Nₖ)

exists and defines a continuous function of c.

Hooley proved that the limiting distribution is exponential: f(c) = 1 - e^{-c}.
-/
theorem erdos235 :
    ∃ f : ℝ → ℝ, Continuous f ∧
      ∀ c : ℝ, 0 ≤ c →
        Tendsto (fun k => gapFraction k c) atTop (nhds (f c)) :=
  sorry

end

content.thinking:
Now I have a good sense of the style. Let me also check a prime gaps conjecture to see how `nth Nat.Prime` is used.

For conjecture 5, the statement is:
- Let $p_n$ be the $n$-th prime.
- For any $C \geq 0$, there exists an infinite sequence $n_i \to \infty$ such that $\lim_{i \to \infty} \frac{p_{n_i+1} - p_{n_i}}{\log n_i} = C$.

Equivalently: every $C \geq 0$ is a limit point of the sequence $(p_{n+1} - p_n) / \log n$ (where $n$ is the index of the prime, not the prime itself).


I'm noticing the normalization here uses $\log n_i$ (the log of the index) rather than $\log p_{n_i}$ (the log of the prime itself), which is different from the typical normalized gap in prime gap theory.

But since the prime number theorem tells us $p_n \sim n \log n$, these two normalizations are asymptotically equivalent—the ratio $\log p_n / \log n$ approaches 1. So whether I divide the gap by $\log n$ or $\log p_n$, the limit points of the resulting sequence are the same.

This means I can formalize the conjecture as: every non-negative real number $C$ appears as a limit point of the sequence of normalized gaps.

Setting up the Lean formalization...

I need to define the prime gap sequence using `nth Nat.Prime` and normalize it by dividing by the logarithm of the index. Since we're working with natural numbers that need to be cast to reals for the division, I have to be careful with type conversions—the difference `(p (n+1) : ℝ) - (p n : ℝ)` needs to be divided by `Real.log (n : ℝ)`. The limit as $i \to \infty$ handles the edge case where logarithm might be undefined at small values.

The conjecture I'm formalizing states that for any non-negative real $C$, there exists a strictly increasing function $f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ such that the normalized prime gaps along the subsequence $f(i)$ converge to $C$. I'm still clarifying whether $C$ can be infinite or if we're only considering finite values. I need to figure out the right formalization approach—whether to use extended reals or just stick with finite values. The problem statement seems to ask whether every non-negative real $C$ (and possibly $+\infty$) appears as a limit point, but for the Lean formalization, I'll focus on finite $C \geq 0$ and handle the infinite case separately if needed. I need to decide whether to formalize this in `ℝ` or `EReal` — using `ℝ` captures all finite limit points as `[0, ∞)`, but misses `+∞`, while `EReal` handles both cleanly. The simplest approach might be stating that for every non-negative $C$, there's an infinite subsequence converging to $C$. I should also clarify the indexing convention since Mathlib's `Nat.nth Nat.Prime` is 0-indexed.

Now I'm realizing the denominator should use $\log n_i$ (the log of the index), not $\log p_{n_i}$ (the log of the prime itself), which is what the problem statement specifies.

Setting up Lean code... Now I'm laying out the formal conjecture: whether the set of limit points equals the entire non-negative reals including infinity, which would mean for any target value C, we can find infinitely many prime gaps that converge to C when normalized by the logarithm. I'm noting some of the major breakthroughs—Westzynthius proved infinity is achievable, Goldston-Pintz-Yıldırım showed zero is, and earlier work established that the set has positive measure, though the full conjecture remains open.

Formalizing this in Lean...

Now I need to verify the imports—I'll need modules for natural number sequences, prime definitions, logarithms, filters, and topology to properly express the limit behavior and tendsto relationship. I'm realizing that a strictly monotone function from ℕ to ℕ automatically tends to infinity since `f n ≥ n`, so `StrictMono f` is sufficient. For the normalized gap, I'm using `(nthPrime (f i + 1) - nthPrime (f i)) / log (f i + 1)` with 0-indexing where `nthPrime 0 = 2`, and I need to clarify whether the denominator should be `log n_i` or `log (n_i + 1)` based on the problem statement. I'm working through the indexing carefully—the cleanest approach is to define a normalized prime gap function that takes a 0-indexed position and computes the gap between consecutive primes divided by the logarithm of that position plus one, which sidesteps the log(0) issue while keeping the denominator aligned with the 1-based indexing from the problem statement.

Now I need to figure out the right Lean formulation and gather the necessary Mathlib imports...

Setting up the Lean code... I'm reviewing the known results toward this conjecture, starting with Westzynthius's 1931 proof that arbitrarily large prime gaps exist, through to more recent work showing that at least 12.5% of the non-negative reals belong to S.

Formalizing the conjecture in Lean... Writing the function definition... I need to fix the type coercion issue—since `n` is a natural number, I can't directly coerce `n + 1` to a real without first converting `n` itself. The cleanest approach is to write `((n : ℝ) + 1)` in the logarithm argument. Now I'm thinking through what imports I'll need, particularly checking what 235.lean already brings in from Mathlib.

Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic and Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic for the filter and limit machinery, and whether I need anything additional for the topology and limit operations to work properly.

I need to make sure the `normalizedPrimeGap` definition is marked as noncomputable since it involves real number arithmetic, which the `noncomputable section` will handle. Now I'm ready to write out the complete file and test whether it compiles with these imports.

1→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Trigonometric.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Order.ConditionallyCompleteLattice.Basic
     5→
     6→open BigOperators Real
     7→
     8→/--
     9→A square placement in ℝ²: a center point, a positive side length, and a
    10→rotation angle (in radians) measuring how far the square is rotated from
    11→the standard axis-aligned orientation.
    12→-/
    13→structure SquarePlacement where
    14→  center : ℝ × ℝ
    15→  side   : ℝ
    16→  angle  : ℝ
    17→  side_pos : 0 < side
    18→
    19→/--
    20→The closed region occupied by a square placement.  A point p lies in the
    21→region iff, when translated so the center is at the origin and then rotated
    22→by `-angle`, its coordinates both lie in `[-side/2, side/2]`.
    23→-/
    24→noncomputable def SquarePlacement.region (sq : SquarePlacement) : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
    25→  {p : ℝ × ℝ |
    26→    let u :=  (p.1 - sq.center.1) * cos sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * sin sq.angle
    27→    let v := -(p.1 - sq.center.1) * sin sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * cos sq.angle
    28→    |u| ≤ sq.side / 2 ∧ |v| ≤ sq.side / 2}
    29→
    30→/--
    31→The open interior of a square placement (strict inequalities).
    32→-/
    33→noncomputable def SquarePlacement.sqInterior (sq : SquarePlacement) : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
    34→  {p : ℝ × ℝ |
    35→    let u :=  (p.1 - sq.center.1) * cos sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * sin sq.angle
    36→    let v := -(p.1 - sq.center.1) * sin sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * cos sq.angle
    37→    |u| < sq.side / 2 ∧ |v| < sq.side / 2}
    38→
    39→/--
    40→The unit square [0,1]² ⊆ ℝ².
    41→-/
    42→def unitSquare : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
    43→  {p : ℝ × ℝ | 0 ≤ p.1 ∧ p.1 ≤ 1 ∧ 0 ≤ p.2 ∧ p.2 ≤ 1}
    44→
    45→/--
    46→A valid configuration of `n` squares inside the unit square:
    47→1. Each square's closed region is contained in the unit square.
    48→2. No two distinct squares share an interior point (their open interiors
    49→   are disjoint).
    50→-/
    51→def IsValidSquareConfig (n : ℕ) (config : Fin n → SquarePlacement) : Prop :=
    52→  (∀ i : Fin n, (config i).region ⊆ unitSquare) ∧
    53→  (∀ i j : Fin n, i ≠ j → Disjoint (config i).sqInterior (config j).sqInterior)
    54→
    55→/--
    56→`f n` is the supremum of the total side-length sum over all valid configurations
    57→of `n` (possibly rotated) squares inside the unit square with pairwise disjoint
    58→interiors.
    59→-/
    60→noncomputable def f (n : ℕ) : ℝ :=
    61→  sSup {s : ℝ | ∃ config : Fin n → SquarePlacement,
    62→    IsValidSquareConfig n config ∧ s = ∑ i : Fin n, (config i).side}
    63→
    64→/--
    65→Erdős Problem #106:
    66→
    67→Draw `n` squares (not necessarily axis-aligned) inside the unit square [0,1]²
    68→with no two squares sharing a common interior point.  Let `f(n)` be the maximum
    69→possible sum of the side-lengths of the squares.
    70→
    71→**Conjecture**: `f(k² + 1) = k` for every positive integer `k`.
    72→
    73→Background:
    74→- It follows easily from the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality that `f(k²) = k`.
    75→- The lower bound `f(k² + 1) ≥ k` is elementary: subdivide [0,1]² into k²
    76→  squares of side 1/k, then replace any one of them by two squares of side
    77→  1/(2k); the total side-length is (k² − 1)/k + 2·(1/(2k)) = k.
    78→- The conjecture asserts that this lower bound is tight: no configuration of
    79→  k² + 1 squares can exceed the total side-length k achievable with k² squares.
    80→- Baek, Koizumi, and Ueoro (2024) proved the axis-aligned variant: if all
    81→  squares are required to have sides parallel to the coordinate axes, then the
    82→  supremum equals k.
    83→-/
    84→theorem erdos_problem_106 :
    85→    ∀ k : ℕ, 0 < k → f (k ^ 2 + 1) = (k : ℝ) :=
    86→  sorry
    87→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Trigonometric.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Order.ConditionallyCompleteLattice.Basic

open BigOperators Real

/--
A square placement in ℝ²: a center point, a positive side length, and a
rotation angle (in radians) measuring how far the square is rotated from
the standard axis-aligned orientation.
-/
structure SquarePlacement where
  center : ℝ × ℝ
  side   : ℝ
  angle  : ℝ
  side_pos : 0 < side

/--
The closed region occupied by a square placement.  A point p lies in the
region iff, when translated so the center is at the origin and then rotated
by `-angle`, its coordinates both lie in `[-side/2, side/2]`.
-/
noncomputable def SquarePlacement.region (sq : SquarePlacement) : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
  {p : ℝ × ℝ |
    let u :=  (p.1 - sq.center.1) * cos sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * sin sq.angle
    let v := -(p.1 - sq.center.1) * sin sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * cos sq.angle
    |u| ≤ sq.side / 2 ∧ |v| ≤ sq.side / 2}

/--
The open interior of a square placement (strict inequalities).
-/
noncomputable def SquarePlacement.sqInterior (sq : SquarePlacement) : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
  {p : ℝ × ℝ |
    let u :=  (p.1 - sq.center.1) * cos sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * sin sq.angle
    let v := -(p.1 - sq.center.1) * sin sq.angle + (p.2 - sq.center.2) * cos sq.angle
    |u| < sq.side / 2 ∧ |v| < sq.side / 2}

/--
The unit square [0,1]² ⊆ ℝ².
-/
def unitSquare : Set (ℝ × ℝ) :=
  {p : ℝ × ℝ | 0 ≤ p.1 ∧ p.1 ≤ 1 ∧ 0 ≤ p.2 ∧ p.2 ≤ 1}

/--
A valid configuration of `n` squares inside the unit square:
1. Each square's closed region is contained in the unit square.
2. No two distinct squares share an interior point (their open interiors
   are disjoint).
-/
def IsValidSquareConfig (n : ℕ) (config : Fin n → SquarePlacement) : Prop :=
  (∀ i : Fin n, (config i).region ⊆ unitSquare) ∧
  (∀ i j : Fin n, i ≠ j → Disjoint (config i).sqInterior (config j).sqInterior)

/--
`f n` is the supremum of the total side-length sum over all valid configurations
of `n` (possibly rotated) squares inside the unit square with pairwise disjoint
interiors.
-/
noncomputable def f (n : ℕ) : ℝ :=
  sSup {s : ℝ | ∃ config : Fin n → SquarePlacement,
    IsValidSquareConfig n config ∧ s = ∑ i : Fin n, (config i).side}

/--
Erdős Problem #106:

Draw `n` squares (not necessarily axis-aligned) inside the unit square [0,1]²
with no two squares sharing a common interior point.  Let `f(n)` be the maximum
possible sum of the side-lengths of the squares.

**Conjecture**: `f(k² + 1) = k` for every positive integer `k`.

Background:
- It follows easily from the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality that `f(k²) = k`.
- The lower bound `f(k² + 1) ≥ k` is elementary: subdivide [0,1]² into k²
  squares of side 1/k, then replace any one of them by two squares of side
  1/(2k); the total side-length is (k² − 1)/k + 2·(1/(2k)) = k.
- The conjecture asserts that this lower bound is tight: no configuration of
  k² + 1 squares can exceed the total side-length k achievable with k² squares.
- Baek, Koizumi, and Ueoro (2024) proved the axis-aligned variant: if all
  squares are required to have sides parallel to the coordinate axes, then the
  supremum equals k.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_106 :
    ∀ k : ℕ, 0 < k → f (k ^ 2 + 1) = (k : ℝ) :=
  sorry

content.thinking:
Now I have a good understanding of the style. Let me write the Lean formalization for problem 5.

The conjecture: for any $C \geq 0$, there exists an infinite sequence $n_i \to \infty$ such that $\frac{p_{n_i+1} - p_{n_i}}{\log n_i} \to C$.

In Lean:
- Use `Nat.nth Nat.Prime` for primes (0-indexed)
- The normalized gap at index `n` is `(nth Nat.Prime (n+1) - nth Nat.Prime n) / log(n+1)` (using `n+1` to avoid log(0))


- The formal statement expresses that for any non-negative real $C$, there's a strictly increasing subsequence of indices whose normalized prime gaps converge to $C$
- I'll need to import the necessary modules for prime numbers, natural number indexing, and logarithm functions

, along with the topological concepts for limits and neighborhoods
- I've confirmed that `Nat.nth` is available in `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Nth` and can be used with `open Nat` to access `nth Nat.Prime`

Now I'm ready to write out the formalization in Lean 4.

content.text: Now I have enough context. Let me write the formalization.

input.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Nth
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic

open Filter Nat Real

noncomputable section

/--
The normalized prime gap at index n (0-indexed):
  (p_{n+1} - p_n) / log(n+1)
where p_n = nth Nat.Prime n is the n-th prime (so p_0 = 2, p_1 = 3, …).
We use n+1 in the denominator so that log is evaluated at a positive argument.
-/
def normalizedPrimeGap (n : ℕ) : ℝ :=
  ((nth Nat.Prime (n + 1) : ℝ) - (nth Nat.Prime n : ℝ)) / Real.log ((n : ℝ) + 1)

/--
Erdős Problem #5 [Er55c, Er57, Er61, Er65b, Er85c, Er90, Er97c]:

Let pₙ denote the n-th prime. Let S be the set of limit points of the sequence
  (p_{n+1} - pₙ) / log n.
The conjecture asserts S = [0, ∞], i.e., every value C ∈ [0, ∞] is attained as
a limit along some subsequence.

Formally (for finite C): for every C ≥ 0 there exists a strictly increasing
sequence of indices n₁ < n₂ < ⋯ such that
  (p_{nᵢ+1} - p_{nᵢ}) / log nᵢ → C   as i → ∞.

Known results toward this conjecture:
- ∞ ∈ S (Westzynthius 1931): prime gaps are unbounded relative to log n.
- 0 ∈ S (Goldston–Pintz–Yıldırım 2009): normalized gaps can be arbitrarily small.
- S has positive Lebesgue measure (Erdős 1955; Ricci 1956).
- S contains arbitrarily large finite numbers (Hildebrand–Maier 1988).
- [0, c] ⊆ S for some c > 0 (Pintz 2016).
- At least 12.5% of [0, ∞) belongs to S (Banks–Freiberg–Maynard 2016).
- At least 1/3 of [0, ∞) belongs to S, and S has bounded gaps (Merikoski 2020).
-/
theorem erdos_problem_5 :
    ∀ C : ℝ, 0 ≤ C →
      ∃ f : ℕ → ℕ, StrictMono f ∧
        Tendsto (fun i => normalizedPrimeGap (f i)) atTop (nhds C) :=
  sorry

end

import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Nth
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic

open Filter Nat Real

noncomputable section

/--
The normalized prime gap at index n (0-indexed):
  (p_{n+1} - p_n) / log(n+1)
where p_n = nth Nat.Prime n is the n-th prime (so p_0 = 2, p_1 = 3, …).
We use n+1 in the denominator so that log is evaluated at a positive argument.
-/
def normalizedPrimeGap (n : ℕ) : ℝ :=
  ((nth Nat.Prime (n + 1) : ℝ) - (nth Nat.Prime n : ℝ)) / Real.log ((n : ℝ) + 1)

/--
Erdős Problem #5 [Er55c, Er57, Er61, Er65b, Er85c, Er90, Er97c]:

Let pₙ denote the n-th prime. Let S be the set of limit points of the sequence
  (p_{n+1} - pₙ) / log n.
The conjecture asserts S = [0, ∞], i.e., every value C ∈ [0, ∞] is attained as
a limit along some subsequence.

Formally (for finite C): for every C ≥ 0 there exists a strictly increasing
sequence of indices n₁ < n₂ < ⋯ such that
  (p_{nᵢ+1} - p_{nᵢ}) / log nᵢ → C   as i → ∞.

Known results toward this conjecture:
- ∞ ∈ S (Westzynthius 1931): prime gaps are unbounded relative to log n.
- 0 ∈ S (Goldston–Pintz–Yıldırım 2009): normalized gaps can be arbitrarily small.
- S has positive Lebesgue measure (Erdős 1955; Ricci 1956).
- S contains arbitrarily large finite numbers (Hildebrand–Maier 1988).
- [0, c] ⊆ S for some c > 0 (Pintz 2016).
- At least 12.5% of [0, ∞) belongs to S (Banks–Freiberg–Maynard 2016).
- At least 1/3 of [0, ∞) belongs to S, and S has bounded gaps (Merikoski 2020).
-/
theorem erdos_problem_5 :
    ∀ C : ℝ, 0 ≤ C →
      ∃ f : ℕ → ℕ, StrictMono f ∧
        Tendsto (fun i => normalizedPrimeGap (f i)) atTop (nhds C) :=
  sorry

end

content.text:
Build succeeded with only the expected `sorry` warning. The formalization is at `conjectures/5.lean`.

**Summary of the formalization:**

The conjecture asks whether every $C \geq 0$ is a limit point of the sequence $\frac{p_{n+1} - p_n}{\log n}$ (i.e., whether the set of limit points $S = [0, \infty]$).

The Lean statement uses:
- `normalizedPrimeGap n` = `(nth Nat.Prime (n+1) - nth Nat.Prime n) / log(n+1)` — the normalized gap at the 0-indexed prime $p_n$
- A strictly monotone `f : ℕ → ℕ` to pick out the subsequence $n_i$
- `Tendsto ... atTop (nhds C)` for the limit condition

The theorem states: for every `C : ℝ` with `0 ≤ C`, there exists a strictly increasing sequence of indices along which the normalized gap converges to `C`.
